Ingest_LDD.name: EPN VESPA Local Dictionary 2.0
Ingest_LDD.comment:
This EPN VESPA LDD version propose a flat architecture corresponding to EPN VESPA attributes.
Features: - all EPN VESPA attributes at same level in XML label
Current issues: - c1min, c1max, c2min, c2max, c3min and c3max can't have @unit. This will be problematic for mapping with other LDDs, and make validation more complex. - s_region is provided is an STC string. No validation process. - bib_reference should be split in various subtypes for validation - particle_spectral_*_min and particle_spectral_*_max units can't be described (no @unit) - access_format missing ASCII_Mime_Type value_data_type - attributes missing _min/_max split: subsolar_longitude, subsolar_latitude, subobserver_longitude, subobserver_latitude, ra, dec, radial_distance, altitude_fromshape, mass, sideral_rotation_period, mean_radius, equatorial_radius, polar_radius

DD_Attribute.name: granule_uid
DD_Attribute.definition: Unique granule ID in data service. There can be only one product associated to a granule (plus possibly a thumbnail for quick-look purpose in a search interface).

DD_Attribute.name: granule_gid
DD_Attribute.definition: Common to granules of same type (e.g. same map projection, or geometry data products) - think of it as a simple and convenient way to group or differentiate types of data. When several files relate to the same data, this parameter helps distinguishing them. This will allow the user to select the type of data of interest. E. g., a service may provide links to calibrated images, plus raw data and ancillary information for every granule; these will share the same obs_id, but will have different granule_gid.

DD_Attribute.name: obs_id
DD_Attribute.definition: Associates granules derived from the same data (e.g. various representations / processing levels). May be the ID of original observation.

DD_Attribute.name: dataproduct_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The dataproduct_type parameter describes the high level scientific organization of the data product linked by the access_url parameter (see below), or directly included in the table (in which case the value is most likely 'ca' for catalogue). EPNCore currently defines several types listed below. The data provider must select the type most adapted to his data. In complex situations (e. g., when a file contains several data products), several types can be used to describe the same granule — although using several granules to describe the file content may be a better solution.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Image. scalar field with two spatial axes, or association of several such fields, e.g., images with multiple color planes, from multichannel or filter cameras. Preview images (e.g. map with axis and caption) also belong here. Conversely, all vectorial 2D fields are described as catalogue

Map. scalar field / rasters with two spatial axes covering a large area and projected either on the sky or on a planetary body, associated to a Projection parameter (with a short enumerated list of possible values). This is mostly intended to identify complete coverages that can be used as reference basemaps.

Spectrum. measurements organized primarily along a spectral axis, e.g., radiance spectra. This includes spectral aggregates (series of related spectra with non-connected spectral ranges, e.g., from several channels of the same instrument)
Dynamic Spectrum. consecutive spectral measurements through time, organized primarily as a time series. This typically implies successive spectra of the same target / field of view.

Spectral Cube. sets of spectral measurements with 1 or 2D spatial coverage, e.g., imaging spectroscopy. The choice between image and spectral_cube is dictated by the characteristics of the instrument (which dimension is most resolved and, which dimensions are acquired simultaneously). The choice between dynamic_spectrum and spectral_cube is related to the uniformity of the field of view.
Profile. scalar or vectorial measurements along 1 spatial dimension, e.g., atmospheric profiles, atmospheric paths, sub-surface profiles, traverses...
Volume. other measurements with 3 spatial dimensions, e.g., internal or atmospheric structures, including shells/shape models (3D surfaces).
Movie. sets of chronological 2D spatial measurements

Cube. multidimensional data with 3 or more axes, e.g., all that is not described by other 3D data types such as spectral cube or volume. This is mostly intended to accommodate unusual data with multiple dimensions.

Time Series. measurements organized primarily as a function of time (with exception of dynamical spectra and movies, i.e. usually a scalar quantity). Typical examples of time series include space-borne dust detector measurements, daily or seasonal curves measured at a given location (e.g. a lander), and light curves.

Catalogue. applies to a single granule providing a list of events, a catalog of object parameters, a list of features... "Spatial vectors" (e.g., vector information from a GIS, spatial footprints...) belong here. This is relevant, e. g., for collections of vectorial elements (e.g. crater lists or ROI definitions) which can be handled directly in a specialized environment such as a GIS. This includes maps of vectors, e.g., wind maps.

Catalogue Item. applies when the service itself provides a catalogue, with entries described as individual granules. The service can be, e. g., a list of asteroid properties or spectral lines. Catalogue_item can be limited to scalar quantities (including strings), and possibly to a single element. This organization allows the user to search inside the catalogue from the TAP query interface.

DD_Attribute.name: target_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_name element identifies a target by name or ID. The target may be any Solar System body, exoplanet, planetary sample, or meteorite, plus in some cases astronomical objects or spacecraft. Any other feature (craters, regions, atmospheric layers…) must be named using the optional feature_name parameter. This parameter can be multivalued only to describe several targets related to a product; alternative names of the same target can be provided through the optional alt_target_name parameter. The best practice is to use the official designation of the target as defined by IAU. This parameter is case sensitive (mixing lower/upper cases) and all values must use the standard spelling and case. Data providers must be aware that services which do not use the IAU designations might not be accessible by the clients. Conversely, users must be aware that some services containing data of interest might not be visible, if they do not use the recommended IAU nomenclature for planetary bodies. The SSODnet name resolver provided by VOParis-IMCCE may help data providers (and users as well) to handle multiple denominations

DD_Attribute.name: target_class
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_class element identifies the type of a named target. A target is defined without ambiguity by a couple of parameters: target_class and target_name (although some targets may have no proper name)

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: asteriod
dwarf planet
planet
natural satellite
comet
exoplanet
interplanetary medium (mostly interplanetary dust)
planetary ring
lunar or planetary samples, to meteorites, but also to terrestrial samples, e.g., in laboratory studies.
sky
spacecraft
spacejunk (free floating spacecraft, spacecraft or rocket debris)
star
calibration target

DD_Attribute.name: time_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The time_min parameter provide the start date and time of acquisition in the observer frame. Time parameters are provided in UTC and formatted in Julian days (expressed as a double precision float).

DD_Attribute.name: time_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The time_max parameter provide the end date and time of acquisition in the observer frame. Time parameters are provided in UTC and formatted in Julian days.

DD_Attribute.name: time_sampling_step_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The time_sampling_step_min parameter provides the sampling step for measurements of dynamical phenomena, and for computations.

DD_Attribute.name: time_sampling_step_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The time_sampling_step_max parameter provides the sampling step for measurements of dynamical phenomena, and for computations.

DD_Attribute.name: time_exp_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The time_exp_min parameter correspond to the integration time (or exposure time) of measurements.

DD_Attribute.name: time_exp_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The time_exp_max parameter correspond to the integration time (or exposure time) of measurements.

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_range_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_range_min parameter define the lower bound of the spectral domain of the data. This quantity must be conventionally expressed on a frequency scale in Hertz, in this context.

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_range_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_range_max parameter define the upper bound of the spectral domain of the data. This quantity must be conventionally expressed on a frequency scale in Hertz, in this context.

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_sampling_step_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_sampling_step_min parameter the minimal spectral separation between the centers of two adjacent filters or channels. Like all spectral_* quantities, it is expressed on a frequency scale in Hz.

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_sampling_step_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_sampling_step_max parameter the maximal spectral separation between the centers of two adjacent filters or channels. Like all spectral_* quantities, it is expressed on a frequency scale in Hz.

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_resolution_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_resolution_min parameter correspond to the smallest spectral bandwidth used for the measurement (Full Width at Half Maximum).

DD_Attribute.name: spectral_resolution_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The spectral_resolution_max parameter correspond to the largest spectral bandwidth used for the measurement (Full Width at Half Maximum).

DD_Attribute.name: c1min
DD_Attribute.definition: The c1min parameter provides the lowest bound of the 1st coordinate.

DD_Attribute.name: c1max
DD_Attribute.definition: The c1max parameter provides the upper bound of the 1st coordinate.

DD_Attribute.name: c2min
DD_Attribute.definition: The c2min parameter provides the lowest bound of the 2nd coordinate.

DD_Attribute.name: c2max
DD_Attribute.definition: The c2max parameter provides the upper bound of the 2nd coordinate.

DD_Attribute.name: c3min
DD_Attribute.definition: The c3min parameter provides the lowest bound of the 3rd coordinate.

DD_Attribute.name: c3max
DD_Attribute.definition: The c3max parameter provides the upper bound of the 3rd coordinate.

DD_Attribute.name: s_region
DD_Attribute.definition: Type of s_region object, written as an STC string.

DD_Attribute.name: c1_resol_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min resolution in first coordinate

DD_Attribute.name: c1_resol_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max resolution in first coordinate

DD_Attribute.name: c2_resol_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min resolution in 2nd coordinate

DD_Attribute.name: c2_resol_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max resolution in 2nd coordinate

DD_Attribute.name: c3_resol_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min resolution in 3rd coordinate

DD_Attribute.name: c3_resol_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max resolution in 3rd coordinate

DD_Attribute.name: spatial_frame_type
DD_Attribute.definition: Provides the "flavor" of the coordinate system, which defines the nature of the spatial coordinates (c1,c2,c3) in the epn_core table and queries, and the way they are defined. This may be different from the coordinate system associated to / included in the data themselves. A value is required (use "none" if not applicable, "body" may also be OK in most cases). This parameter, although related to the specific coordinate system in use, is mostly intended to identify the nature of the coordinates handled by the service (e. g., angles versus distances).

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: to be used when no spatial frame is defined for the dataset. This is intended to prevent useless searches when space coordinates are not defined.

2D angles on the sky, i.e., right ascension c1 and declination c2 + possibly heliocentric distance in c3 - although this is a special case of spherical frame, the order and conventions are different. Earth distance may be provided as target_distance whenever relevant (ground-based observations). Assumes ICRS coordinates; right ascension is provided in degrees.

2D angles in body-fixed frame: longitude c1 and latitude c2 + possibly altitude (above a reference surface) as c3. (c3 is expected to only provide an order of magnitude in general, not to be a fine search parameter) Planetocentric system with eastward longitudes in the range (0,360) degres is expected. Current IAU frame is assumed, in particular for definition of prime meridian. IAU 2009 planetocentric convention [RD12] applies, in particular eastward longitudes and a north pole located on the north side of the invariant plane of the Solar System for planets and satellites (see [RD12] for small bodies, and Annex A for details).
(x,y,z) as (c1,c2,c3). This includes spatial coordinates given in pixels.

(r, theta, phi) as (c1,c2,c3), as defined in ISO standard 80000-2:2009; r = radius; theta = zenith angle/colatitude/inclination; phi = azimuth (E longitude). Angles are provided in degrees. When related to the sky or to a solid body, "celestial" (with RA/Dec) or "body" (with longitude/latitude) coordinates must be used instead.
(r, theta, z) as (c1,c2,c3); r = radius; theta = azimuth; z = height. The angle is provided in degrees.

DD_Attribute.name: incidence_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min incidence angle (solar zenithal angle)

DD_Attribute.name: incidence_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max incidence angle (solar zenithal angle)

DD_Attribute.name: emergence_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min emergence angle

DD_Attribute.name: emergence_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max emergence angle

DD_Attribute.name: phase_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min phase angle

DD_Attribute.name: phase_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max phase angle

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_host_name
DD_Attribute.definition: Standard name of the observatory or spacecraft

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_name
DD_Attribute.definition: Standard name of instrument

DD_Attribute.name: measurement_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The measurement_type parameter defines the physical quantities contained in the data, using UCDs. It relates to the reported quantity, not to the type of experiment. Therefore only UCD related to physical quantities can be used; e.g., phys.absorption;em.opt.I is eligible, while stellar_occultation is not. The provider must use the "UCD1+" list from IVOA as a reference, and should extend it only when necessary.

DD_Attribute.name: processing_level
DD_Attribute.definition: In the framework of EPN-TAP, this parameter is intended to provide the user with a quick evaluation of data "usability". Several classifications are in use in different contexts, as summarized in the table below. EPNCore v2 uses the CODMAC levels / PDS3 but removes the intermediate calibration levels; this is equivalent to using the simplified PDS4 levels and maintaining a separated level for ancillary data. "Partially calibrated" datasets are in general considered as not calibrated, but this evaluation is up to the data provider depending on context. "Ancillary" data include all extra information documenting the measurements, in particular coordinates or geometry files. Although it may be more consistent to separate calibration levels in different data services, several levels can be included in the same service (in particular calibrated and ancillary data). Only one value can be accommodated in this field, so the most advanced level (1-5) must be used whenever several levels are available in the same granule

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Unprocessed Data Record: Low-level encoding, e.g. telemetry from a spacecraft instrument. Normally available only to the original team. Corresponding level in other nomenclatures: - CODMAC = 1 - raw - PSA = 1a - NASA = N/A - PRODUCT_TYPE (PS3/PSA) = UDR - PDS4 = Telemetry - ObsCore = Level 0

Experiment Data Record: often referred to as "raw data": decommutated, but still affected by instrumental effects. Corresponding level in other nomenclatures: - CODMAC = 2 - edited - PSA = 1b - NASA = 0 - PRODUCT_TYPE (PS3/PSA) = EDR - PDS4 = Raw - ObsCore = Level 1

Reduced Data Record: "calibrated" in physical units. Corresponding level in other nomenclatures: - CODMAC = 3 - calibrated - PSA = 2 - NASA = 1A - PRODUCT_TYPE (PS3/PSA) = RDR - PDS4 = Calibrated - ObsCore = Level 2

Reformatted Data Record: mosaics or composite of several observing sessions, involving some level of data fusion. Corresponding level in other nomenclatures: - CODMAC = 4 - resampled - PSA = N/A - NASA = 1B - PRODUCT_TYPE (PS3/PSA) = REFDR - PDS4 = Derived - ObsCore = N/A Derived Data Record: result of data analysis, directly usable by other communities with no further processing. Corresponding level in other nomenclatures: - CODMAC = 5 - derived - PSA = 3 - NASA = 2 to 5 - PRODUCT_TYPE (PS3/PSA) = DDR - PDS4 = Derived - ObsCore = 3

Ancillary Data Record: extra data specifically supporting a data set, such as coordinates, geometry... Corresponding level in other nomenclatures: - CODMAC = 6 - ancillary - PSA = N/A - NASA = N/A - PRODUCT_TYPE (PS3/PSA) = ANCDR - PDS4 = Derived - ObsCore = N/A

DD_Attribute.name: creation_date
DD_Attribute.definition: Date of first entry of this granule

DD_Attribute.name: modification_date
DD_Attribute.definition: Date of last modification (used to handle mirroring)

DD_Attribute.name: release_date
DD_Attribute.definition: Start of public access period (set to creation_date if no proprietary period)

DD_Attribute.name: service_title
DD_Attribute.definition: Title of resource (an acronym really, will be used to handle multiservice results)

DD_Attribute.name: access_url
DD_Attribute.definition: URL of the data file, case sensitive. If present, access_estsize and access_format parameters must also be present.

DD_Attribute.name: access_format
DD_Attribute.definition: File format type (MIME type), e.g.: text/plain, application/binary, image/fits...

DD_Attribute.name: access_estsize
DD_Attribute.definition: Estimate file size in kbyte

DD_Attribute.name: access_md5
DD_Attribute.definition: MD5 Hash for the file when available

DD_Attribute.name: thumbnail_url
DD_Attribute.definition: URL of a thumbnail image with predefined size (file format = PNG (preferred), GIF, JPG, file size below 500 pix, for use in a client only)

DD_Attribute.name: file_name
DD_Attribute.definition: Name of the data file only, case sensitive

DD_Attribute.name: species
DD_Attribute.definition: Identifies a chemical species, case sensitive

DD_Attribute.name: filter
DD_Attribute.definition: Identifies a filter in use (e.g. imaging)

DD_Attribute.name: alt_target_name
DD_Attribute.definition: This parameter introduces an alternative name of the target, especially when it is more usual than the official IAU one (e.g., Halley vs 1P). Another possible usage is to store here a list of all alternative names of the target (e.g., for asteroids: name, number, principal and provisional designations).

DD_Attribute.name: target_region
DD_Attribute.definition: This parameter optionally identifies the region of interest for the resource, in complement to target_name. This parameter only introduces generic regions, not specific local names, which must be handled using the feature_name parameter. Examples of target_region are: interior, surface, subsurface, atmosphere, ionosphere, magnetosphere... The best practice is to take the values from standard sources: - IVOA thesaurus: http://www.ivoa.net/rdf/Vocabularies/vocabularies-20091007/IVOAT/ - IAU thesaurus http://www.mso.anu.edu.au/library/thesaurus/ - another version: http://www.vocabularyserver.com/trex/en/ The latter seems more recent and more complete (although the interface is not practical) - Spase dictionary http://www.spase-group.org/

DD_Attribute.name: feature_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The feature_name parameter introduces a supplementary name to provide more details about the observed target. It is intended in particular to accommodate a local name (crater, surface feature, region name...) whereas target_name is reserved to describe the whole body (Mars, Moon, Ceres…). The best practice is to use the official features name defined by IAU when relevant. The target_region parameter also provides additional information on the target, but is aimed at indicating the global scope of a database (e.g., atmospheric layer, internal structure...).

DD_Attribute.name: bib_reference
DD_Attribute.definition: Bibliographic reference (ADS Bibcode preferred, doi, or other biblio id, URL...)

DD_Attribute.name: internal_reference
DD_Attribute.definition: List of granule_uid(s) in the current service

DD_Attribute.name: external_link
DD_Attribute.definition: Link to a web page providing more details on the granule.

DD_Attribute.name: subsolar_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: Sub-solar point longitude

DD_Attribute.name: subsolar_latitude
DD_Attribute.definition: Sub-solar point latitude

DD_Attribute.name: subobserver_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: Sub-observer point longitude (sub-Earth for ground based observations)

DD_Attribute.name: subobserver_latitude
DD_Attribute.definition: Sub-observer point latitude (sub-Earth for ground based observations)

DD_Attribute.name: ra
DD_Attribute.definition: Right Ascension

DD_Attribute.name: dec
DD_Attribute.definition: Declination

DD_Attribute.name: radial_distance
DD_Attribute.definition: Distance from center (in body-fixed frame)

DD_Attribute.name: altitude_fromshape
DD_Attribute.definition: Altitude above shape model / DTM (in body-fixed frame)

DD_Attribute.name: solar_longitude_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min Solar longitude Ls (location on orbit / season)

DD_Attribute.name: solar_longitude_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max Solar longitude Ls (location on orbit / season)

DD_Attribute.name: local_time_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min value of Local time at observed region

DD_Attribute.name: local_time_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max value of Local time at observed region

DD_Attribute.name: target_distance_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_distance_min parameter provides the lower bound of the distance of the observer to the observed area.

DD_Attribute.name: target_distance_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The target_distance_min parameter provides the upper bound of the distance of the observer to the observed area.

DD_Attribute.name: target_time_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min value of Observing time in target frame

DD_Attribute.name: target_time_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max value of Observing time in target frame

DD_Attribute.name: earth_distance_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min value of Earth-target distance

DD_Attribute.name: earth_distance_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max value of Earth-target distance

DD_Attribute.name: sun_distance_min
DD_Attribute.definition: Min value of Sun-target distance

DD_Attribute.name: sun_distance_max
DD_Attribute.definition: Max value of Sun-target distance

DD_Attribute.name: particle_spectral_type
DD_Attribute.definition: This parameter and the following ones are related to the spectral distribution of particles only (see the spectral_* parameters for electro-magnetic waves). The particle_spectral_type parameter introduces the type of axis in use: either energy (provided in eV), mass (in amu), or mass/charge ratio (in amu/qe).

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Energy spectrum, in eV
Mass spectrum, in amu
Mass/charge spectrum, in amu/qe

DD_Attribute.name: particle_spectral_range_min
particle_spectral_range_max
particle_spectral_sampling_step_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The particle_spectral_sampling_step_min parameters provide the minimal spectral separation between measurements, in the same scale and unit as particle_spectral_range_min and particle_spectral_range_max.

DD_Attribute.name: particle_spectral_sampling_step_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The particle_spectral_sampling_step_max parameter provides the maximal spectral separation between measurements, in the same scale and unit as particle_spectral_range parameters.

DD_Attribute.name: particle_spectral_resolution_min
DD_Attribute.definition: The particle_spectral_resolution_min parameter provides to the minimal spectral resolution of the measurements, in the same scale and unit as particle_spectral_range parameters.

DD_Attribute.name: particle_spectral_resolution_max
DD_Attribute.definition: The particle_spectral_resolution_max parameter provides to the maximal spectral resolution of the measurements, in the same scale and unit as particle_spectral_range parameters.

DD_Attribute.name: mass
DD_Attribute.definition: Mass of the object

DD_Attribute.name: sideral_rotation_period
DD_Attribute.definition: Sideral rotation period of the object

DD_Attribute.name: mean_radius
DD_Attribute.definition: Mean radius of an object

DD_Attribute.name: equatorial_radius
DD_Attribute.definition: Equatorial radius of an object

DD_Attribute.name: polar_radius
DD_Attribute.definition: Polar radius of an object

DD_Attribute.name: publisher
DD_Attribute.definition: Resource publisher

DD_Attribute.name: spatial_coordinate_description
DD_Attribute.definition: The spatial_coordinate_description parameter provides description of the spatial frame in use, as introduced by the spatial_frame_type parameter.

DD_Attribute.name: spatial_origin
DD_Attribute.definition: Spatial_origin may be used to distinguish between altitude and distance from center when body coordinates are in use

DD_Attribute.name: time_origin
DD_Attribute.definition: This attribute states where the time is measured, and is expected to remain constant throughout the service. This knowledge is required to cross-correlate event-based observations, in particular to indicate light-path differences. It applies to the time_min and time_max parameters (target_time always refers to the target in the FoV). If this parameter is not informed, time is expected to be provided in the observer frame. Possible values for time_origin are: Earth, (solar system bodies), (spacecraft)

DD_Attribute.name: time_scale
DD_Attribute.definition: Default is UTC in data services (may be relaxed in computational services such as ephemeris).

DD_Class.name: VESPA_EPNcore_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This is the wrapper class for all VESPA EPNcore attributes and classes. This is what you include in your label to use the VESPA dictionary.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:time_min) or not(epn:time_max) or epn:time_min <= epn:time_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: time_min must be lower or equal than time_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:time_sampling_step_min) or not(epn:time_sampling_step_max) or epn:time_sampling_step_min <= epn:time_sampling_step_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: time_sampling_step_min must be lower or equal than time_sampling_step_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:time_exp_min) or not(epn:time_exp_max) or epn:time_exp_min <= epn:time_exp_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: time_exp_min must be lower or equal than time_exp_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:spectral_range_min) or not(epn:spectral_range_max) or epn:spectral_range_min <= epn:spectral_range_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: specral_range_min must be lower or equal than specral_range_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:spectral_sampling_step_min) or not(epn:spectral_sampling_step_max) or epn:spectral_sampling_step_min <= epn:spectral_sampling_step_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: spectral_sampling_step_min must be lower or equal than spectral_sampling_step_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:spectral_resolution_min) or not(epn:spectral_resolution_max) or epn:spectral_resolution_min <= epn:spectral_resolution_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: spectral_resolution_min must be lower or equal than spectral_resolution_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:c1_resol_min) or not(epn:c1_resol_max) or epn:c1_resol_min <= epn:c1_resol_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: c1_resol_min must be lower or equal than c1_resol_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:c2_resol_min) or not(epn:c2_resol_max) or epn:c2_resol_min <= epn:c2_resol_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: c2_resol_min must be lower or equal than c2_resol_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:c3_resol_min) or not(epn:c3_resol_max) or epn:c3_resol_min <= epn:c3_resol_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: c3_resol_min must be lower or equal than c3_resol_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:incidence_min) or not(epn:incidence_max) or epn:incidence_min <= epn:incidence_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: incidence_min must be lower or equal than incidence_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:emergence_min) or not(epn:emergence_max) or epn:emergence_min <= epn:emergence_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: emergence_min must be lower or equal than emergence_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:phase_min) or not(epn:phase_max) or epn:phase_min <= epn:phase_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: phase_min must be lower or equal than phase_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:solar_longitude_min) or not(epn:solar_longitude_max) or epn:solar_longitude_min <= epn:solar_longitude_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: solar_longitude_min must be lower or equal than solar_longitude_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:local_time_min) or not(epn:local_time_max) or epn:local_time_min <= epn:local_time_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: local_time_min must be lower or equal than local_time_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:target_distance_min) or not(epn:target_distance_max) or epn:target_distance_min <= epn:target_distance_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: target_distance_min must be lower or equal than target_distance_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:target_time_min) or not(epn:target_time_max) or epn:target_time_min <= epn:target_time_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: target_time_min must be lower or equal than target_time_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:earth_distance_min) or not(epn:earth_distance_max) or epn:earth_distance_min <= epn:earth_distance_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: earth_distance_min must be lower or equal than earth_distance_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:sun_distance_min) or not(epn:sun_distance_max) or epn:sun_distance_min <= epn:sun_distance_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: sun_distance_min must be lower or equal than sun_distance_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:particle_spectral_range_min) or not(epn:particle_spectral_range_max) or epn:particle_spectral_range_min <= epn:particle_spectral_range_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: particle_specral_range_min must be lower or equal than particle_specral_range_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:particle_spectral_sampling_step_min) or not(epn:particle_spectral_sampling_step_max) or epn:particle_spectral_sampling_step_min <= epn:particle_spectral_sampling_step_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: particle_spectral_sampling_step_min must be lower or equal than particle_spectral_sampling_step_max

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: not(epn:particle_spectral_resolution_min) or not(epn:particle_spectral_resolution_max) or epn:particle_spectral_resolution_min <= epn:particle_spectral_resolution_max
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: particle_spectral_resolution_min must be lower or equal than particle_spectral_resolution_max
